grammar_tables.title: Development of nominal endings from PIE to Latin
grammar_tables.description: Note "(<)" abbreviates "(fused with last stem sound (consonant or vowel))", "(<<)" abbreviates "(fused with last stem vowel + consonant)", "(–)" abbreviates "(previous vowel is lengthened)", "?(x)" means "possibly x", "(x|y)" means "either x or y".

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European (simplified)
grammar_table.description: This table omits the dual number, of which the development of Latin retains few if any traces. Not depicted, but part of Italic development: Pre-laryngeal e-ablauts were already laryngeally colored (i.e. phonetically eh₂ has become ah₂, and h₂e h₂a; p. 63; p. 244; p. 29; p. 42-50). Variations in athematic root/stem accent/ablaut are ignored except for a few cases where stem ablauts easily fuse with the endings proper. Regarding nominative singular consonant-stems nouns, most scholars assume an -s ending, and for that -s ending to be dropped (with compensatory lengthening of the preceding vowel) after non-stops. p. 186 though assumes the opposite, consonant-stem nouns originally ending in -∅, with -s only copied over later from the o-stem nouns. For stems ending in -n- and -(d|t)-, the stem-final consonant may have dropped too, with any subsequent -s only kept in the latter (example *kwō from *kwon-: Beekes p. 194, Sihler p. 100, 230; example *pōs from *pod-: Sihler p. 130, 280; not depicted: Sihler p. 280 assumes for *pod- that the dental stop was later analogically restored, with the lengthened vowel kept: *pōts .) The accusative plural endings in -ns probably result from suffixing the plural nominative -s to the accusative singular -m ( p. 2084; Meier-Brügger p. 295). Not depicted: a thematic singular genitive in -os, only to be found in the Anatolian brnach (Klein/Joseph/Fritz p. 2086), with -os?(i)o probably an early import from the pronouns (Beekes p. 213)..

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European eh₂ (feminine) declension
grammar_table.description: Possibly after the split-off of the Anatolian branch, an explicitely feminine declension emerges, marked by a -eh₂- stem suffix to which athematic endings are appended ( p. 189; p. 132-133; p. 323-324, 334-335, 421; p. 131; p. 245, 266). The singular vocative is a special case, with different theories about its form and the logic behind it.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Late Proto-Indo-European bʰ/m-branching
grammar_table.description: In the Italic branch (among others), the endings starting in either -m- or -bʰ- generalize the latter.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic loss of laryngeals, and Proto-Indo-European laryngeal coloring
grammar_table.description: The laryngeals disappear. Vowels neighboring lost laryngeals are left in their phonetic laryngeal coloring (i.e. -e- as -a- when neighbor to -h₂-), and lengthened if the lost laryngeal came after and was word-final or followed by a consonant ( p. 149-150; p. 9-10; p. 63-64; p. 244; p. 28-30, 56-57; p. 42-50). Word-final post-consonantal laryngeals (maybe even after -u: Meiser p. 147) become -a (Sihler p. 99; Meiser p. 107). From these changes, vowel neighborships -aa- (a-stem dative singular), -āā- (a-stem instrumental singular) and (possibly with the a-stem genitive/ablative singular) -ao- emerge that contract to -ā- (Meiser p. 87-88; Sihler p. 83). Post-laryngeal continuation of former eh₂-stem singular instrumental ending -eh₂bʰi is not directly discussed in the literature, but would have given -ābʰi by these rules. The a-stem singular vocative form reflects no single rule path, but an uncertainty that fits the variety of theories about its original form. The i/u-stem singular instrumentals in -ī (<) and -ū (<) are not directly attested for Italic, but are the logical result of the above rules also found in Vedic and Avestan and speculatively included here as such (Fortson p. 116, Sihler p. 312, 323).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic fusion of (dative-)ablative and instrumental
grammar_table.description: Ablative and instrumental fuse to the new ablative ( p. 14-15; p. 281; p. 128; p. 252-253, 258), in the plural together with the formally already identical dative (Meiser p. 128-129, Sihler p. 264): The o-stem instrumental plural ending -ōis replaces the dative/ablative ending. The a-stem dative/ablative plural ending is re-shaped after the result to -āis. In the singular, the pattern of the o-stem ablative ending -ōd is generalized to all other stems. (There may have been an intermediate stage where the singular instrumental endings -ā, -ē, -ī, -ū replaced the old ablative endings not as distinctive as -ōd, and were then re-shaped by mere addition of its -d.)

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic influence of Osthoff's Law
grammar_table.description: As per Osthoff's Law, long vowels before resonants are shortened if the latter are followed by consonants ( p. 75; p. 58).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic plural ablative/dative/locative
grammar_table.description: In the plurals, dative/ablative and locative fuse to one common form per stem. In the a/o-stems, this form is identical to the plural dative/ablative's original form. In the o-stems, the result of -ois would have been equal to the locative ending -oisu on loss of its -u ( p. 74), which may have happened at the same time. This formal identity between dative/ablative and locative may have spread to the other stems. The extension of the athematic dative/ablative to the locative is barely speculative (Meiser p. 129 "mag verwendet worden sein") and therefore not depicted.

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic plural athematic ablative/dative
grammar_table.description: For the athematic plural ablative/dative ending, no trace of -?(i)- is discussed in the literature. The ending is furthermore affected by the Italic changes to voiced aspirates, which turn -bʰ- in medial positions to either -f- or the voiced bilabial fricative -β- ( p. 139-141, 145, 147, p. 101-103, p. 51-52).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic assimilation of e to o before u
grammar_table.description: Before u, (short) e becomes o ( p. 40, 56; p. 59). The u-stem plural nominative/locative in -oues is here depicted as the regular result, although Sihler p. 325 states: "for some reason, that is not generally regarded as likely."

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic (?) contraction of -eie- to -ē-
grammar_table.description: The singular i-stem dative ending in -eiei is contracted to -ei, either by haplology ( p. 139, p. 187), or by a regular Proto-Italic loss of intervocalic -i- ( p. 188, "arguably in [Proto-Italic]"; more safely with Meiser p. 91) shortening -eiei to -eei, which regularly becomes -ēi (Sihler p. 83, Meiser p. 87). Loss of intervocalic -i- would also explain the development of the i-stem nominative/vocative plural ( p. 102, Szemerényi p. 187).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: The o-stem singular genitive from Celtic to Latino-Faliscan
grammar_table.description: Proto-Indo-European -os?(i)o is continued as -osio even into Archaic Latin. An ending -ī of uncertain origin replaces this in later Latin, but also turns up in Venetic (which, if part of the Italic family, split off from it early; p. 25; p. 127, 465-466), Faliscan, and even Celtic languages. This may continue a Proto-Italic or even Proto-Italo-Celtic ending. Or it may be the result of more recent morphological borrowing between languages in close contact on the Italian Peninsula ( p. 32). The -ī ending may continue a suffix -iH that marks familial affiliation (Beekes p. 212; p. 333; p. 135).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Proto-Italic (?) vowel shortening before -m
grammar_table.description: Long vowels before -m are shortened ( p. 78, p. 77). The chronology is disputed. The shortening is shared with Celtic and Slavic, so might be early; but regular sound change would then have turned endings in -am into -em (Sihler p. 65). There is also evidence for -ām in Italic Oscan. Meiser opts for a late change, while Sihler explains away outliers to the expected development from an early change by leveling / influence from other endings that contain -a- (in Latin) or -ā- (in Oscan).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Italic convergence of endings in -a
grammar_table.description: All previous endings in -a and -ā converge to -a, as do the plural neuter i-/u-stem endings. The paths to this differ greatly between and . For Sihler, endings in -ā at first prevail over endings in -a (a-stem singular vocative turns to -ā under the influence of the nominative (p. 268), and the consonantic plural neuter under the influence of the o-stem (p. 263)), and later ("[r]elatively late in the history of [Latin]", but "predat[ing] the loss of final -d") all word-final -ā turn to -a, due to "iambic shortening", the influence of the shortened -am ending, or a mysteriously singular vowel shift (p. 78-79, 266-267). Meiser cannot accept such a vowel shift (p. 77) and proposes an inverse generalization of -a endings prevailing over -ā endings (p. 132, 136). Sihler (p. 317, 326) sees the plural neuter o-stem endings in -ā append to the i-/u-stem endings (with -ī- and -ū- shortening to -i- and -u-, as long vowels shorten before long ones (p. 80)) before turning to -a. Meiser (p. 144, 146-147) sees the consonant stem ending in -a replace the original i/u-stem neuter plural endings, but also proposes alternate paths for the u-stem: an ending in -a deriving from the -h₂ in a former -?(e)uh₂ (p. 147).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: Pronoun influence in Proto-Italic and Latino-Faliscan
grammar_table.description: Already in Proto-Italic, the a-stem plural genitive ending is replaced by the pronoun ending of the same case ( p. 272, p. 757, p. 236). The o-stem plural animate nominative, on the other hand, is only replaced by the respective pronoun ending after the split from Sabellic (which went the opposite way: Sihler p. 261).

declension_def.title: consonant-stem in velar or bilabial stop

grammar_table.title: proto-italic
grammar_table.description: Note that p. 286 names -fos as the Proto-Italic dative-ablative consonant stem plural ending, but this (even if reflected in all other Italic languages) is inconsistent with Early Latin's reflex of original -bʰos as -bos ( p. 147, 286), so the earlier form is here given. The dative singular is somewhat aritrarily chosen as the proto-italic starting point for the fusion of consonant and i-stem paradigms ( p. 316, 318), with other forms still separate. The i-stem genitive singular is unsure, at least the one continued in Latin ( p. 316-317). The u-stem nominative/vocative/accusative neuter singular is unsure, the table uses what p. 323 describes as the PIE ending, and p. 16 describes as one possible Early Latin form. The u-stem dative/ablative plural is assumed to be the same as for consonant and i-stems, although p. 326 only securely names it for PIE. Not depicted: neuter r/n-stems ( p. 298-299).

declension_def.title: consonant stem not in vowel + -r/-n or dental

grammar_table.title: classical
grammar_table.description: -o- becomes -u- before final consonants ( p. 66), -e- becomes -i- before non-nasal consonants (general rule with some exception, but holds true before any final consonants) ( p. 65), nominative/vocative -ros/-re/-ris becomes -r after vowels (not for i-stems) and -er after consonants ( p. 70), vocative -ie and genitive -iī become -ī ( p. 256, 260), dative -ōi and ablative -ōd become -ō ( p. 58, 228), word-final -ns becomes -s with lengthening of preceding vocal ( p. 215), -ā becomes -a ( p. 78), introduction of singular genitive in -ī ( p. 260), -ois becomes -eis becomes -īs ( p. 263), same with -āis ( p. 272), o-stem genitive plural partly modeled after a-stem ( p. 264), o-stem nominative plural is replaced from the pronoun -oi becoming -ei becoming -ī ( p. 260), same with a-stem nominative plural ( p. 271), long vowels before -m got short ( p. 78), -āi shortened to -ae ( p. 268), loss of word-final -d after a long vowel ( p. 228), in a-stem plural dative-ablative –īs is replaced with -ābus where necessary to avoid homophony with o-stem plural dative-ablatives ( p. 272), intervocalic -s becomes -r ( p. 171-172), word-final -ss becomes -s ( p. 204-205), (former) dorsal stop plus -s becomes -x ( p. 204), -ei- in final syllable becomes -ī ( p. 70), final -i becomes -e ( p. 65), either the consonant locative or (less likely) instrumental singular becomes the consonant ablative singular ( p. 285), consonant locative singular in -ī is modeled in analogy to o-stems ( p. 285), the -bus derived from the -b- reflex to word-internal -bʰ- ( p. 145, 147) and got an -i- prefix ( p. 286), the i-stem plural nominative ending -ēs becomes the consonant plural nominative ending proper ( p. 286), -rs becomes -rr becomes in final position -r ( p. 211), former root stems in -s whose -s- became -r- intervocalic sometimes retain -s in the nominative singular ( p. 310-311), long vowels before final non-s consonants shorten ( p. 79), l-stems emerge from other stem-forms (-n-, -l/n-) ( p. 304), some neuter s-stems (notable exception: root nouns) analogize the rhotacized stem ending (-r-) to the nominative singular ( p. 306, 309) the -on- suffix of consonant stems is reflected as medial -in- ( p. 60-61, 295-296), consonant stem endings encroach on i-stem endings ( p. 318), i-stems in -nd-, -nt-, -rt- end in -s (<<), with lengthening of preceding vowel if -ns results ( p. 316), i-stem neuter nominative/vocative singulars lost their end vowel on mono-syllabic stems ( p. 69), i-stem genitive singular -is evolves either from consonant stem encroachment or an original ending in -es ( p. 316-317), u-stem dative singular in -ū emerges via unclear paths ( p. 323), -ou- became -u- ( p. 62), u-stem singular nominative/vocative/accusative emerges somehow ( p. 323), u-stem singular genitive in -ūs (<) somehow emerges from -ous and in -is from -(e|o)s, the latter maybe in some analogy to i-stems, while the Old Latin innovation -ī (<) is lost ( p. 324), u-stem plural animate nominative/vocative emerges from unknown etymology ( p. 325), certain animate n-stem nouns with nominative singular in -en emerge from gender change, compounds with the weakened root "can-", and unclear etymology ( p.296, 298), i-stem plural animate nominative/vocative -eies becomes -ees (loss of intervocalic -i-, p. 188) becomes -ēs ( p. 317), i-stem plural inaminate nominative/vocative/accusative gets the consonant ending -a appended ( p. 317), long vowels shorten before other vowels ( p. 80), u-stem dative/ablative plurals mostly mirror the common -ibus, with -ubus (<) maybe not so much an original form but a later-day practice to avoid homophony ( p. 326), the 5th or ē-stem declension emerges, fusing various different paradigms into one ( p. 340-343). Not depicted: u-stem (or rather: ū-stem) freak cases "sūs" and "grūs" ( p. 328). Not depicted: Freak case "Iuppiter"/"Iovis" ( p. 338-339). Not depicted: Freak case "bōs"/"bovis" ( p. 334-336). Not depicted relationship: animate i-stem nouns with accusative singular in -im always form the ablative singular to -ī ( p. 316). Not depicted: i- and mixed-stem freak cases of "senex"/"senis", "urbs"/"urbis", "nox"/"noctis", and s-stem root nouns with genitive plural in -ium, and the opposite with nominative singular in -is and otherwise consonant-stem endings ( p. 319). Not depicted: kinship nouns of animate consonant stems in -r with nominative singular in -er (<) (like "pater"/"patris") ( p. 293). Not depicted: The consonant stems in -n- freak cases of "carō"/"carnis", "iuvenis"/"iuvenis", "sangu(i|ī)s"/"sanguinis", "liēn"/"li(e|ē)nis", "fel"/"fellis" ( p. 291, 295-296, 298). Not depicted: The consonant stems in -l- freak cases of "sāl"/"salis", "fel"/"fellis", "mel"/"mellis" ( p. 304). Not depicted: The root noun freak cases of "vīs" and "spēs"/"speī" ( p. 311). Not depicted: Neuter r/n-stems freak cases of "femur"/"feminis", "iecur"/"iocineris", "iter"/"itineris" p. 298-299). Not depcited: Nouns in -ēs nominative singular, mostly behaving like i-stem nouns ( p. 316). Not depicted: Heteroclitic nouns that may inflect to more than one paradigm ( p. 344-345). A locative plural in -īs is too speculative ( p. 253 alone mentions it, prefixed with a "perhaps") to include in the table.

declension_def.title: consonant stem in dental and some stems in -r formerly in -s
consonant stem in (former) dorsal (g, c, v, h)
consonant stem not in dental, dorsal, or -r/-n

bibliography.book: Beekes, Robert S. P.: Comparative Indo-European Linguistics: an Introduction. Second Edition. John Benjamins 2011.
Clackson, James / Horrocks, Geoffrey: The Blackwell History of the Latin Language. Blackwell 2007.
Fortson, Benjamin W.: Indo-European Language and Culture: an Introduction. Second Edition. Blackwell 2010.
Meier-Brügger, Michael: Indogermanische Sprachwissenschaft. 9. durchgesehene und ergänzte Auflage. De Gruyter 2010.
Meiser, Gerhard: Historische Laut- und Formenlehre der lateinischen Sprache. 2. Auflage. Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft 2002.
Sihler, Andrew L.: New Comparative Grammar of Greek and Latin. Oxford University Press 1995.
Szemerényi, Oswald: Einführung in die vergleichende Sprachwissenschaft. 4., durchgesehene Auflage. Wissenschaftliche Buchgesellschaft 1990.
Klein, Jared & Joseph, Brian & Fritz, Matthias: Handbook of Comparative and Historical Linguistics. De Gruyter 2017.
Weiss, Michael: Outline of the Historical and Comparative Grammar of Latin. Beech Stave Press 2009.
